hawaiian_text: Ma keia kaao ana, ua olelo ia ke kino o Kana, he kino loihi loa, a he kino nui a weliweli ke nana aku. I kona hanai ia ana, ua panee kona kino i ka loihi, a ua panee no hoi kona hale o Halauoloolo; mai ke kuahiwi a kokoke i ke kai kona kino ka loihi, a pela iho la no ke ako ana o ka hale, o Halauoloolo.
reference_translation: In this legend it is said that the body of Kana grew to be very tall and large and was terrible to behold. While he was being brought up, he grew so fast that the house had to be lengthened, so that it extended from the mountain until it was almost to the edge of the sea. Such is the story as told of this house, Halauoloolo.
deepseek-r1-0528-dsapi_translation:
Here is the English translation of the Hawaiian text:

<translation>In this story, it is said that the body of Kana was a body very, very long, and a body huge and terrifying to behold. When he was raised, his body stretched to great length, and his house, Halauoloolo, also stretched; his body extended from the mountains down to near the sea, and so too did the ridgepole of the house, Halauoloolo.</translation>

**Key Translation Points:**
*   **kino o Kana:** body of Kana
*   **kino loihi loa:** body very, very long
*   **kino nui a weliweli ke nana aku:** body huge and terrifying to look at
*   **I kona hanai ia ana:** When he was raised/nourished
*   **ua panee kona kino i ka loihi:** his body stretched/extended to great length
*   **hale o Halauoloolo:** house of Halauoloolo (a proper name)
*   **mai ke kuahiwi a kokoke i ke kai:** from the mountain to near the sea
*   **kona kino ka loihi:** his body the length/extent
*   **ke ako ana o ka hale:** the ridgepole (or possibly the length/height) of the house
